title: Delivering Most-Favored-Nation Prescription Drug Pricing to American Patients

enrichment.summary: This executive order directs federal agencies to ensure American patients pay no more for prescription drugs than the lowest prices available in other developed countries. It tasks agencies with negotiating drug prices, enabling direct-to-consumer sales at these prices, and taking enforcement actions against unfair foreign and domestic pharmaceutical pricing practices. The goal is to end price discrimination that causes Americans to subsidize global pharmaceutical costs.
potential_concerns: Pharmaceutical manufacturers may reduce investment in research or attempt legal challenges in response to price controls.
Importation and direct-to-consumer programs could raise concerns over drug safety and supply chain integrity.
Enforcement against foreign nations on drug pricing might create diplomatic tensions or trade disputes.
Efforts to impose most-favored-nation pricing could lead to unintended drug shortages or reduced drug availability.
Administrative challenges in coordinating multiple federal agencies and implementing price negotiation rules quickly.
